CSC 422.description: Introduction to network and web security, including denial of service, botnets, access control, routing attacks, transport layer attacks, tunneling mechanisms, VPNs, IDS, firewalls, penetration testing, key distribution, browser security, social network security, email security, jamming, and wireless security.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/CSC 422.
CSC 422.title: Network and Web Security

CSC 424.description: Principles behind secure software design including threat models, trust management, common vulnerabilities and mitigation techniques, robust software development, isolation of untrusted code, auditability, and testing.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 424.title: Software Security

CSC 429.description: Selected topics in emerging areas of computer security.  Potential topics include:  network and web security, critical infrastructure protection, embedded systems security, malware analysis, mobile security, and digital forensics, among others.  The Schedule of Classes will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 429.title: Current Topics in Computer Security

CSC 430.description: Construction of the front end of a compiler including lexical analysis, syntactic analysis, type checking, and formal semantics.  Introduction to regular languages, finite automata, and context-free grammars.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 430.title: Programming Languages I

CSC 431.description: Language principles and design issues:  bindings, conversion, parameter passing, and dynamic semantics.  Language implementation:  intermediate code representation, memory management, code optimization, and code generation.  Functional programming languages.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/CSC 431.
CSC 431.title: Programming Languages II

CSC 435.description: Principles of object-oriented design, with emphasis on use of these principles in the design of graphical interfaces.  Comparison and contrasting of two major object-oriented languages and their corresponding GUI class libraries.  Language-independent object-oriented design methods, and application of these methods in the construction of a GUI-based project.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 435.title: Introduction to Object Oriented Design Using Graphical User Interfaces

CSC 436.description: Inception, development, testing, and deployment of mobile applications.  Introduction to tools, libraries, and frameworks for one or more mobile platforms and devices.  Emphasis on software engineering best practices for developing entrepreneurial or humanitarian mobile-centric applications.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 436.title: Mobile Application Development

CSC 437.description: Project-based study of web-based three-tiered applications, including current best practices and tools for design, implementation and testing of browser interface, serverside business logic, object-relational mapping, databases, and web services.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 437.prereqs: CPE/CSC 357 with a grade of C- or better and CSC 365 with a grade of C- or better; or consent of instructor
CSC 437.title: Dynamic Web Development

CSC 445.description: Theory of formal languages and automata.  Turing machines.  Chomsky hierarchy.  Theory of decidability and computability.  4 lectures.
CSC 445.title: Theory of Computation I

CSC 448.description: Introduction to the use of computers to solve problems in molecular biology.  The algorithms, languages, and databases important in determining and analyzing nucleic and protein sequences and their structure.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 448.title: Bioinformatics Algorithms

CSC 450.description: Team-based design, construction and deployment of a collaborative interactive computational art project typically found in the fields of animation, game design, and interactive media.  Management of inter-disciplinary teams, documentation, creative development, testing, and assessment.  2 laboratories.  Crosslisted as ART/CSC 450.
CSC 450.title: Computing for Interactive Arts Capstone II

CSC 453.description: Introduction to sequential and multiprogramming operating systems; kernel calls, interrupt service mechanisms, scheduling, files and protection mechanisms, conventional machine attributes that apply to operating system implementation, virtual memory management, and I/O control systems.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/CSC 453.
CSC 453.prereqs: CSC/CPE 357, and CSC/CPE 225 or CPE/EE 229 or CPE/EE 233
CSC 453.title: Introduction to Operating Systems

CSC 454.description: Design and implementation of multiprogramming kernels, systems programming methodology, interprocess communications, synchronization, device drivers and network access methods.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/CSC 454.
CSC 454.title: Implementation of Operating Systems

CSC 458.description: Selected aspects of design, implementation and analysis of networks, advanced operating and distributed systems.  Topics may include process management, virtual memory, process communication, context switching, file system designs, persistent objects, process and data migration, load balancing, security and networks.  The Schedule of Classes will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/CSC 458.
CSC 458.title: Current Topics in Computer Systems

CSC 466.description: Overview of modern knowledge discovery from data (KDD) methods and technologies.  Topics in data mining (association rules mining, classification, clustering), information retrieval, web mining.  Emphasis on use of KDD techniques in modern software applications.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 466.prereqs: CSC 349 and one of the following: STAT 302, STAT 312, STAT 321 or STAT 350
CSC 466.title: Knowledge Discovery from Data

CSC 468.description: Data structures and algorithms used in the implementation of database systems.  Implementation of data and transaction managers:  access methods interfaces, concurrency control and recovery, query processors and optimizers.  Introduction to implementation of distributed database systems.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 468.title: Database Management Systems Implementation

CSC 469.description: Foundations of distributed systems, distributed hash tables (peer-to-peer systems), failure detectors, synchronization, election, inter-process communication, consensus, replication, key-value stores, and measurements.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CSC/CPE 469.
CSC 469.title: Distributed Systems

CSC 471.description: Graphics software development and use of application programming interfaces for 3D graphics.  The graphics pipeline, modeling, geometric and viewing transforms, lighting and shading, rendering, interaction techniques and graphics hardware.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/CSC 471.
CSC 471.title: Introduction to Computer Graphics

CSC 473.description: Illumination models, reflectance, absorption, emittance, Gouraud shading, Phong shading, raytracing polyhedra and other modeling primitives, coherence, acceleration methods, radiosity, form factors, advanced algorithms.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 473.title: Advanced Rendering Techniques

CSC 474.description: Basic and advanced algorithms for generating sequences of synthetic images.  Interpolation in time and space, procedural and keyframe animation, particle systems, dynamics and inverse kinematics, morphing and video.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 474.title: Computer Animation

CSC 476.description: Basic and advanced algorithms for real-time, interactive, 3D graphics software.  Modeling (polygon mesh, height field, scene graph), real-time rendering and shading (visibility processing, LOD, texture and light maps), collision detection (bounding volumes, complexity management), interactive controls, multi-player game technology, game engine architecture.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/CSC 476.
CSC 476.title: Real-Time 3D Computer Graphics Software

CSC 477.description: Basic data processing (magnitude, grouping and segmentation), visualization design, cognition and perception, spatial data visualizations (2D and 3D, e.g.  GIS data, medical data) information data visualization, spatial encoding, color encoding, and interaction.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 477.title: Scientific and Information Visualization

CSC 478.description: Selected aspects of the design, implementation and analysis of computer graphics.  Topics may include rendering, modeling, visualization, animation, virtual reality, computer vision, multimedia, and perception issues.  The Schedule of Classes will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 478.title: Current Topics in Computer Graphics

CSC 480.description: Programs and techniques that characterize artificial intelligence.  Programming in a high level language.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 480.prereqs: either CSC/CPE 102 and CSC/CPE 103 with a grade of C- or better or consent of instructor; or CSC/CPE 202 and CSC/CPE 203 with a grade of C- or better or consent of instructor
CSC 480.title: Artificial Intelligence

CSC 481.description: In-depth treatment of knowledge representation, utilization and acquisition in a programming environment.  Emphasis on the use of domain-specific knowledge to obtain expert performance in programs.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 481.title: Knowledge Based Systems

CSC 483.description: Selected aspects of the field of human-computer interaction.  Topics may include dynamic information visualization, universal access, social impact of technology usage, educational technology, human cognition and performance studies, and extended usability evaluation techniques.  The Schedule of Classes will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 483.title: Current Topics in Human-Computer Interaction

CSC 484.description: Introduction to the importance of user-centered principles in the design of good interfaces and effective human-computer interaction.  Topics include:  study of human characteristics affected by interface design, effective requirements data collection and analysis, user-centered approaches to software engineering, and evaluation of interface and interaction quality.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 484.title: User-Centered Interface Design and Development

CSC 486.description: Application of the theories of human-computer interaction to the task of user-centered design.  Survey of techniques for studying and involving users in different aspects of the design process, and demonstration of where and when applicable.  Combining of theoretical understanding with practical experience to design solutions to problems facing interactive systems designers.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 486.title: Human-Computer Interaction Theory and Design

CSC 489.description: Selected aspects of the design, implementation and analysis of advanced systems and concepts in the area of artificial intelligence.  Topics may include knowledge representation, reasoning, learning, or planning, and specific techniques like intelligent agents, genetic algorithms, semantic web, or robotics.  The Schedule of Classes will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 489.title: Current Topics in Artificial Intelligence

CSC 490.description: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  Class schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.
CSC 490.title: Selected Advanced Topics

CSC 491.description: Selection and completion of a project by individuals or team which is typical of problems which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Project may include students from other disciplines.  Formulation of outline, literature review, and project schedule.
CSC 491.prereqs: CSC 307 or CSC 309; and consent of instructor
CSC 491.title: Senior Project I

CSC 492.description: Selection and completion of a project by individuals or team which is typical of problems which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Project may include students from other disciplines.  Project results are presented in a formal report.
CSC 492.title: Senior Project II

CSC 493.description: Part-time work experience in business, industry, government, and other areas of student career interest.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for two consecutive quarters.  Formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  No major credit allowed; total credit limited to 6 units.
CSC 493.prereqs: Sophomore standing and consent of instructor
CSC 493.title: Cooperative Education Experience

CSC 494.description: Full-time work experience in business, industry, government, and other areas of student career interest.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for two consecutive quarters.  Formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  No major credit allowed; total credit limited to 18 units.
CSC 494.prereqs: Sophomore standing and consent of instructor
CSC 494.title: Cooperative Education Experience

CSC 495.description: Full-time work experience in business, industry, government, and other areas of student career interest.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for two consecutive quarters.  A more fully developed formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  No major credit allowed; total credit limited to 24 units.
CSC 495.prereqs: Sophomore standing and consent of instructor
CSC 495.title: Cooperative Education Experience

CSC 496.description: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Schedule of Classes will list title selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.
CSC 496.title: Selected Advanced Laboratory

CSC 500.description: Individual directed study of advanced topics.  Total credit limited to 4 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.
CSC 500.prereqs: Fully classified graduate standing and consent of instructor
CSC 500.title: Directed Study

CSC 508.description: In-depth study of requirements engineering, software project management, formal specifications and object-oriented analysis.  4 seminars.
CSC 508.prereqs: CSC 307 or CSC 308 and graduate standing, or consent of instructor
CSC 508.title: Software Engineering I

CSC 509.description: In-depth study of software modeling and design.  Formal design methodologies.  Design patterns.  Detailed case studies of existing projects.  Tools and methods for designing large software systems.  4 seminars.
CSC 509.prereqs: CSC 508 and graduate standing, or consent of instructor
CSC 509.title: Software Engineering II

CSC 515.description: Comparative study and design of multiprocessor, dataflow, RISC, high level language and other new computer architectures.  VLSI processor design techniques.  3 seminars, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/CSC 515.
CSC 515.prereqs: CPE 315 and graduate standing, or consent of instructor
CSC 515.title: Computer Architecture

CSC 521.description: Exploration of advanced topics in computer security with an emphasis on research topics.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 521.title: Computer Security

CSC 530.description: Advanced programming language and translator concepts.  Language concepts to be covered will be selected from current state-of-the-art languages and current issues in language design.  Compiler concepts will include retargetable code generation, use of translator-writing systems, and error recovery.  4 seminars.
CSC 530.prereqs: CSC 430 and graduate standing, or consent of instructor
CSC 530.title: Languages and Translators

CSC 540.description: Advanced topics in theoretical computer science from such areas as automata theory, cellular automata theory, computational complexity, and program verification.  4 seminars.
CSC 540.prereqs: CSC 445 and graduate standing, or consent of instructor
CSC 540.title: Theory of Computation II

CSC 550.description: General concepts of computer architecture and operating systems.  Design features of advanced computers, general time-sharing systems and schemes for dynamic memory allocation, scheduling and protection.  Dynamic linkage between subroutines.  Intercommunication between input/output and processors.  4 seminars.
CSC 550.prereqs: CSC/CPE 453 and graduate standing, or consent of instructor
CSC 550.title: Operating Systems

CSC 560.description: Current topics in database systems:  distributed databases and transactions, nested and long-running transactions, distributed concurrency control, semantic and object-oriented data models, database systems for non-traditional applications:  engineering design databases, active, logic, temporal, multimedia, and real-time databases.  4 seminars.
CSC 560.prereqs: CSC 365 and graduate standing, or consent of instructor
CSC 560.title: Database Systems

CSC 564.description: Exploration of advanced topics in emerging computer networking technologies; focus on leading edge computer network research topics.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/CSC 564.
CSC 564.prereqs: CSC/CPE 464 and graduate standing, or consent of instructor
CSC 564.title: Computer Networks: Research Topics

CSC 566.description: Advanced topics in the areas of data mining, knowledge discovery in data, machine learning, information retrieval and intelligent analysis of information.  The Schedule of Classes will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  4 lectures.
CSC 566.title: Topics in Advanced Data Mining

CSC 569.description: Principles and practices in distributed computing:  interprocess communications, group communications, client-server model, distributed objects, message queue system, distributed services, mobile agents, object space, Internet protocols.  Distributed algorithms:  consensus protocols, global state protocols.  Fault tolerance:  classification of faults, replication.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/CSC 569.
CSC 569.prereqs: CSC 141 or CSC 348; and CPE/CSC 357; or graduate standing and consent of instructor
CSC 569.title: Distributed Computing

CSC 570.description: Directed group study of selected topics for graduate students.  Topics will normally consist of continuations of those in CSC 520, CSC 530, CSC 540, CSC 550, CSC 560 and CSC 580, and other topics as needed.  Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Topic credit limited to 12 units.  2 to 4 seminars.
CSC 570.prereqs: Graduate standing and evidence of satisfactory preparation in computer science
CSC 570.title: Current Topics in Computer Science

CSC 572.description: Advanced topics in computer graphics with emphasis on leading edge computer graphics technologies and advanced topics in graphics fundamentals.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 572.prereqs: Successful completion of CSC/CPE 471 and graduate standing, or consent of instructor
CSC 572.title: Computer Graphics

CSC 580.description: Current research in the field of artificial intelligence with emphasis on cooperative agents, distributed agents, and decision making in complex, concurrent environments.  AI programming in a distributed environment.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 580.prereqs: CSC 480 and graduate standing, or consent of instructor
CSC 580.title: Artificial Intelligence

CSC 581.description: Methods and techniques that computer-based systems can provide to make the management of knowledge and information in digital form easier for the user.  Emphasis on support for knowledge-intensive activities performed by users.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 581.prereqs: CSC 480 or CSC 484 or consent of instructor
CSC 581.title: Computer Support for Knowledge Management

CSC 582.description: Classic Natural Language Processing systems and techniques; review of recent advancements in the subject.  Topics selected from:  parsing, tagging, word-sense disambiguation, natural language generation, data mining, voice recognition, vocalization, knowledge management, semantic networks, stylistics and machine learning.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
CSC 582.prereqs: CSC 466 or CSC 480 or graduate standing
CSC 582.title: Introduction to Natural Language Processing

CSC 590.description: Preparation for conducting research in the field of computer science, through discussions, selected readings, and student presentations.  1 seminar.
CSC 590.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor
CSC 590.title: Thesis Seminar

CSC 593.description: Advanced study analysis and part-time work experience in student's career field; current innovations, practices, and problems in administration, supervision, and organization of business, industry, and government.  Must have demonstrated ability to do independent work and research in career field.  Credit/No Credit grading only.
CSC 593.prereqs: Graduate standing and consent of instructor
CSC 593.title: Cooperative Education Experience

CSC 594.description: Advanced study analysis and full-time work experience in student's career field; current innovations, practices, and problems in administration, supervision, and organization of business, industry, and government.  Must have demonstrated ability to do independent work and research in career field.  Credit/No Credit grading only.
CSC 594.prereqs: Graduate standing and consent of instructor
CSC 594.title: Cooperative Education Experience

CSC 595.description: Advanced study analysis and full-time work experience in student's career field; current innovations, practices, and problems in administration, supervision, and organization of business, industry, and government.  Must have demonstrated ability to do independent work and research in career field.  A fully-developed formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  Credit/No Credit grading only.
CSC 595.prereqs: Graduate standing and consent of instructor
CSC 595.title: Cooperative Education Experience

CSC 596.description: Individual research or activity under faculty supervision, beginning work on the master's thesis.
CSC 596.prereqs: Graduate standing and consent of instructor
CSC 596.title: Thesis I

CSC 597.description: Individual research or activity under faculty supervision, continuing work on the master's thesis.
CSC 597.title: Thesis II

CSC 599.description: Individual research or activity under faculty supervision leading to an acceptable thesis.
CSC 599.prereqs: CSC 597, selection of thesis committee, graduate standing, and consent of instructor
CSC 599.title: Thesis III

DANC 130.description: Introduction to Joseph Pilates' Physicalmind conditioning method. Development of ideal physical fitness for the attainment and maintenance of a uniformly developed body and sound mind. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.
DANC 130.title: Pilates and Conditioning Fundamentals

DANC 131.description: Fundamentals of ballet technique stressing alignment, turn-out, five basic positions, seven movements of dance, and terminology. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.
DANC 131.title: Beginning Ballet

DANC 132.description: Fundamentals of modern technique stressing alignment, off-centered use of torso, floorwork, movement phrases, and improvisation exercises. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.
DANC 132.title: Beginning Modern Dance

DANC 133.description: Introduction of jazz dance techniques stressing a variety of styles, alignment, isolation, polyrhythms, syncopation, improvisation, and phrasing. Performance technique and presentation of simple dance phrases. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.
DANC 133.title: Beginning Jazz Dance

DANC 134.description: Selected ballroom dances including the cha-cha-cha, foxtrot, merengue, rumba, samba, swing, tango, waltz, and line dance hustle. Emphasis on alignment, etiquette, leading and following, performance techniques, and presentation of simple dance phrases. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.
DANC 134.title: Beginning Ballroom Dance

DANC 135.description: Introduction to international folk dances including round, longway, and square sets. Study of various dance steps, formation, positions, historical and cultural background. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.
DANC 135.title: International Folk Dance

DANC 210.description: Investigation of health and wellness ideologies and techniques for dancers and non-dancers through active participation in fitness circuits and lecture. Elements of fitness, injury prevention, somatic methodologies, anatomy, and body image will be presented and discussed to help students maintain and cultivate optimum health now and in the future. 3 lectures, 1 activity. Fulfills GE D4.
DANC 210.title: Active Wellness

DANC 221.description: Diverse dance forms. Focus on major western dance artists and their works from the 19th century to the present. Cultural context, style and forms in dance. Introductory survey of major experiments in dance. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format. 4 lectures. Fulfills GE C3.
DANC 221.title: Dance Appreciation

DANC 231.description: Continuation of training in basic technical skills in ballet stressing phrasing, performance, and more complex step patterns.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.
DANC 231.prereqs: Intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting
DANC 231.title: Intermediate Ballet

DANC 232.description: Continuing study of DANC 132 with emphasis on various movement styles, phrasing, more complex step patterns, and performance.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.
DANC 232.prereqs: Intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting
DANC 232.title: Intermediate Modern Dance

DANC 233.description: Continuation of DANC 133 with emphasis on more extensive movement vocabulary.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.
DANC 233.prereqs: Intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting
DANC 233.title: Intermediate Jazz Dance

DANC 234.description: Continuation of DANC 134.  Selected ballroom dances:  cha cha, foxtrot, merengue, rumba, swing, tango, hustle, paso doble, polka and samba.  Emphasis on variations, styles, and performance skill.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.
DANC 234.prereqs: DANC 134 or intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting
DANC 234.title: Intermediate Ballroom Dance

DANC 270.description: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Schedule of Classes will list title selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.
DANC 270.prereqs: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor
DANC 270.title: Selected Topics

DANC 280.description: Directed group study of movement techniques and exercises to facilitate expressive physical performance. Body effectiveness, alignment and conditioning practice integrated with creative exploration and movement analysis of effort, spatial awareness and detailed body usage. 4 lectures. Crosslisted as DANC/TH 280.
DANC 280.title: Body Awareness and Expression

DANC 321.description: Multicultural approach to history of dance in America, with emphasis on American Indian, West African, Caribbean, Mexican, European, and Asian contributions and influences.  Explores culture through dance.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) required.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE C4 except for Theatre Arts majors.  Fulfills USCP.
DANC 321.prereqs: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with a grade of C- or better; and GE Area C3
DANC 321.title: Cultural Influence on Dance in America

DANC 331.description: Advanced ballet technique and reconstruction of historical ballet repertories from the romantic, classical, neoclassical, and modern periods.  Participation in dance performance of selected repertory.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.
DANC 331.prereqs: DANC 231 or intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting
DANC 331.title: Advanced Ballet and Repertory

DANC 332.description: Intermediate to advanced dance skills learned through the study and performance of selected contemporary dance repertory.  Addresses problems in advanced performance technique.  Informal presentation in performance situation.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.
DANC 332.prereqs: Intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting
DANC 332.title: Contemporary Dance Repertory

DANC 340.description: Principles of dance composition.  Exploration of creative potential and development of movement motifs through choreographic studies.  Preparation for informal public presentation of student generated choreographic works.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 lecture, 1 laboratory, 2 activities.
DANC 340.prereqs: Intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting
DANC 340.title: Dance Composition

DANC 341.description: Advanced practical application of choreography and dance concert production.  Production of the student-produced Spring Dance Concert will be developed and executed.  Investigation of complete choreographic work via peer and faculty review.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  2 laboratories.
DANC 341.title: Dance Concert Practicum

DANC 345.description: Workshop in concert preparation for major public dance production.  Exploration and process of concert dance choreography.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 16 units.  2 activities, 2 laboratories.
DANC 345.title: Choreography/Workshop in Dance Concert Preparation

DANC 346.description: Directed production of annual Orchesis Dance Company Concert and other public performances.  Attendance of professional dance concert(s) required.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 16 units.  1-4 laboratories.
DANC 346.prereqs: One of the following: DANC 332, DANC 331, or DANC 345
DANC 346.title: Dance Production

DANC 381.description: Dance skills and techniques.  Experience in selected dance forms.  Rhythmic structure and analysis of dance steps.  Includes introduction to dance pedagogy, curricular materials and evaluative procedures.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  2 lectures, 2 activities.
DANC 381.title: Dance Teaching Methods for Dance Minors

DANC 400.description: Individual investigation, research and studies or survey of selected problems in dance and related areas.  Total credit limited to 8 units with a maximum of 4 units per quarter.
DANC 400.prereqs: Consent of instructor and department head
DANC 400.title: Special Problems

DANC 430.description: Directed study of selected topics for advanced dance students.  Focus on advanced level technique, style, concepts and choreography of classical and contemporary dance forms.  The Schedule of Classes will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  2 activities.
DANC 430.title: Advanced Selected Techniques

DANC 470.description: Directed study of selected topics for advanced dance students.  Class Schedule will list topics selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1-4 lectures.
DANC 470.title: Selected Advanced Topics

DANC 471.description: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for dance students.  Class Schedule will list topics selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1-4 laboratories.
DANC 471.title: Selected Advanced Laboratory

DATA 301.description: Introduction to the field of data science and the workflow of a data scientist.  Types of data (tabular, textual, sparse, structured, temporal, geospatial), basic data management and manipulation, simple summaries, and visualization.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DATA 301.title: Introduction to Data Science

DATA 401.description: Principles of data science and big data analytics.  Volume, velocity, and variety of data.  Acquisition, processing, and cleaning of large data-sets.  Analytics for big data.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DATA 401.prereqs: CSC 365, CSC 466, DATA 301, STAT 331 and STAT 419
DATA 401.title: Data Science

DATA 451.description: Working with clients to develop data-driven solutions for systems to be constructed in DATA 452.  Specification and design requirements, elicitation techniques, research and data gathering methods; project planning, time and budget estimating; project team organization.  Ethics and professionalism.  2 laboratories.
DATA 451.title: Data Science Capstone I

DATA 452.description: Team-based design, implementation, deployment and delivery of a system or analytical methodology that involves working with and analyzing large quantities of data.  Technical management of research and development teams.  Technical documentation, quality assurance, integration and systems testing.  Design and conduct of empirical studies.  Visualization and presentation of results orally and in writing.  2 laboratories.
DATA 452.title: Data Science Capstone II

DSCI 100.description: Selection and completion of a management/production project under faculty supervision. Project participation is subject to approval by the project supervisor and the Cal Poly Corporation. Degree credit limited to 12 units. Credit/No Credit grading only.
DSCI 100.title: Enterprise Project

DSCI 102.description: Dairy farm biosecurity, animal handling and welfare, equipment operation, employee safety and hazard analysis. Instruction in standard operating procedures (SOP) relevant to milking, transition cow and calf management and cattle identification. 2 activities.
DSCI 102.title: Dairy Operations and Safety

DSCI 200.description: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.
DSCI 200.title: Special Problems for Undergraduates

DSCI 202.description: National and state dairy promotional programs, advertising and merchandising.  Marketing and pricing of milk and dairy products at the state and national level.  4 lectures.
DSCI 202.title: Dairy Promotion and Marketing

DSCI 230.description: Selection, breeding, feeding, and management of dairy cattle. Composition and food value of dairy products. Milk pricing, political influences, dairy industry statistics and opportunities. Producing and handling products. Intended as introductory course for non-dairy science majors. 3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 230.title: General Dairy Husbandry

DSCI 231.description: Composition and properties of fluid milk and manufactured milk products. Chemistry and microbiology of dairy products. Processes and equipment involved in the manufacture of butter, cheeses, and other fermented dairy products, frozen, condensed, and dried dairy foods. 3 lectures, 1 activity.
DSCI 231.title: General Dairy Manufacturing

DSCI 233.description: Composition and properties of fluid milk and its constituents.  Equipment used to handle, process, and distribute fluid milk and related products.  California dairy codes used for dairy farms and plants, with practice inspections of dairy farms and factories.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 233.title: Milk Processing and Inspection

DSCI 241.description: Selection of dairy cattle on type conformation and the correlation between type and production.  Dairy cattle breeds and breed comparisons.  Techniques to properly condition, groom and present dairy cattle for evaluation and merchandising.  2 lectures, 2 activities.
DSCI 241.title: Dairy Cattle Selection, Breeds, Fitting and Showing

DSCI 270.description: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Schedule of Classes will list title selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.
DSCI 270.prereqs: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor
DSCI 270.title: Selected Topics

DSCI 301.description: Nutrition principles to maximize milk production.  Ruminal and post ruminal digestion, post absorptive metabolism, nutrient interactions and microbiology.  Modern techniques to manipulate and increase animal efficiency.  Use of computer models to evaluate and precisely formulate diets.  3 lectures, 1 activity.
DSCI 301.title: Dairy Cattle Nutrition

DSCI 321.description: Mechanisms of milk component secretion, including protein, lactose and fat metabolism.  Disorders of the mammary gland (mastitis) and control strategies.  Endocrine aspects of mammary gland development and lactogenesis.  4 lectures.
DSCI 321.prereqs: ASCI 220; DSCI 230; and BIO 111 or BIO 161
DSCI 321.title: Lactation Physiology

DSCI 330.description: Techniques in the collection, evaluation and processing of semen, along with embryo culturing and manipulation.  Insemination procedures, fertility problems, record keeping, estrous synchronization, endocrine control of reproduction, treating reproductive disorders and embryo transfer.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 330.title: Artificial Insemination and Embryo Biotechnology

DSCI 333.description: Application of principles of herd health, biosecurity, lactation physiology, cattle management and reproductive physiology to successful dairy operations.  Assessment of animal comfort and general health and well-being.  Practical techniques in safe animal handling.  3 lectures, 1 activity.
DSCI 333.title: Dairy Animal Health, Safety and Applied Technology

DSCI 339.description: Selected Dairy Science students will spend up to 12 weeks with an approved agricultural firm engaged in production or related business.  Time will be spent applying and developing production and managerial skills and abilities.  One unit of credit may be allowed for each full week of completed and reported internship.  Degree credit limited to 12 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.
DSCI 339.title: Internship in Dairy Science

DSCI 340.description: Management of dairy wastes to protect the environment while providing a return on investment.  Selection of waste management systems, considering capital and operating costs and benefits from nutrient, biogas, and heat recovery.  Best practices that meet current regulatory requirements.  3 lectures.
DSCI 340.title: Dairy Waste Management and Resource Recovery

DSCI 400.description: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.
DSCI 400.title: Special Problems for Advanced Undergraduates

DSCI 401.description: Composition, structure and properties of milk and milk products.  Physical and chemical changes that occur during processing and storage of dairy products.  Objective measurement of chemical and physical properties.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 401.title: Physical and Chemical Properties of Dairy Products

DSCI 402.description: Current methods used to evaluate dairy products with respect to plant economics and consumer safety.  Accurate procedures for chemical and biological testing, statistical approach to sampling and design and interpretation of HACCP programs for assuring product quality and safety.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 402.title: Quality Assurance and Control of Dairy Products

DSCI 410.description: Nutrient metabolism and diet formulation technologies for all classes of dairy cattle; whole-farm feed management; physiological and nutritional aspects of predominant metabolic disorders; on-farm auditing and troubleshooting of nutritional management.  Field trip required.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 410.title: Advanced Dairy Nutrition

DSCI 412.description: Student consultation teams of three or four students visit dairies and/or attend management training seminars followed by presenting management recommendations to the dairy owners, consultants, and other industry leaders.  1 seminar and supervised work.
DSCI 412.title: Dairy Farm Consultation

DSCI 422.description: Evaluation of inherited characteristics in dairy cattle, including principles of inheritance and genomic evaluations.  Proving and selecting sires and dams, dairy genetic evaluations.  4 lectures.
DSCI 422.prereqs: DSCI 241, BIO 111 or higher, STAT 130 or higher
DSCI 422.title: Breeding and Genetics of Dairy Cattle

DSCI 432.description: Dairy herd management skills needed in dairy operations.  Instruction and lab experience in management, records, labor, waste management, and milking management.  4 lectures.
DSCI 432.title: Advanced Dairy Herd Management

DSCI 433.description: Basic management principles applied to the dairy industry.  Industrial organization and control.  Dairy plant design, facilities, layout.  Inventory control and records.  Milk pooling and stabilization records.  Maintenance and operation of equipment.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 433.title: Dairy Plant Management and Equipment

DSCI 434.description: Scientific methods, ingredients, and equipment used in the manufacture of various fermented dairy products, including cheeses, buttermilk, sour cream, and yogurt.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 434.prereqs: DSCI 231; MCRO 221 or MCRO 224; and STAT 218
DSCI 434.title: Cheese and Fermented Dairy Foods

DSCI 435.description: Technology of evaporation, drying and membrane separation processes applied to dairy fluids.  Design and performance of evaporators, driers, and membrane processing systems.  Equipment, ingredients, and methods needed to manufacture butter and dairy spreads.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 435.title: Concentration and Fractionation Technology

DSCI 444.description: Microorganisms involved in the fermentation and ripening processes in the dairy industry, as well as those involved in spoilage of milk and dairy products, in the transmission of disease through these products, and indicator systems used to determine sanitary quality of these products.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 444.prereqs: DSCI 233; and MCRO 221 or MCRO 224; and STAT 130 or STAT 218; or graduate standing
DSCI 444.title: Dairy Microbiology

DSCI 461.description: Selection and completion of a project under faculty supervision.  Projects are typical of problems which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Project results are presented in a formal written report.  2 lectures and supervised work.
DSCI 461.title: Senior Project

DSCI 470.description: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.
DSCI 470.title: Selected Advanced Topics

DSCI 471.description: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Schedule of Classes will list title selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.
DSCI 471.title: Selected Advanced Laboratory

DSCI 500.description: Advanced independent study planned and completed under the direction of a member of the Dairy Science faculty.  Total credit limited to 6 units.
DSCI 500.prereqs: Consent of department head, graduate advisor and supervising faculty member
DSCI 500.title: Individual Study in Dairy Science

DSCI 501.description: Composition, structure/functional relationships and properties of milk, milk components and products.  Physical, chemical and biochemical changes that occur during processing, storage and use of milk and milk components.  Chemical, physical, functional and nutritional properties of milk components.  3 lectures.
DSCI 501.prereqs: CHEM 212 or CHEM 312; admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology
DSCI 501.title: Dairy Chemistry

DSCI 502.description: Objective measurements, analysis and isolation of milk components.  Experimental demonstration of chemical and physical reactions of milk components during typical processing conditions.  2 laboratories.
DSCI 502.prereqs: DSCI 501; admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology
DSCI 502.title: Dairy Chemistry Laboratory

DSCI 510.description: Contemporary issues in the dairy foods and allied industries.  Consumer, political, environmental, regulatory, producer, technological, scientific, and economic considerations critical to future industry leaders.  Required field trips to the dairy foods processing industry in California.  1 lecture, 1 activity.
DSCI 510.prereqs: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology
DSCI 510.title: Dairy Foods: Issues and Practices

DSCI 520.description: Principles of unit operations involving heat and mass transfer including pasteurization and related thermal processes, centrifugal separation, concentration processes, churning and related high shear extrusion, fractionation processes, freezing, and drying technologies.  Pneumatic and mechanical devices and systems.  2 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 520.prereqs: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology
DSCI 520.title: Dairy Processing and Manufacturing I

DSCI 521.description: Unit operations in process systems for the efficient manufacture of fluid milk products, cream, butter, and concentrated milk.  Process variables and their control, system integration.  Use of processes to manipulate physical and chemical properties to influence product quality.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 521.prereqs: DSCI 520; admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology
DSCI 521.title: Dairy Processing and Manufacturing II

DSCI 524.description: Unit operations in process systems for the efficient manufacture of fermented milks, cheese, frozen desserts, and dried milk and whey products.  Process variables and their control, system integration for these products.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 524.title: Dairy Processing and Manufacturing III

DSCI 535.description: Identification and industrial use of functional milk fractions.  Physical, chemical, and sensory properties of milk fractions.  Objective and sensory measurements of milk ingredients as used in food and beverage products.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 535.title: Dairy Foods Ingredient Functionality

DSCI 539.description: Application of theory to the solution of problems of agricultural production or related business in the field of Dairy Science.  Analyze specific management problems and perform general management assignments detailed in a contract between the student, the firm or organization, and the faculty advisor before the internship commences.  Degree credit limited to 6 units.
DSCI 539.title: Graduate Internship in Dairy Science

DSCI 540.description: Raw milk microbiological principles, pasteurization and microorganisms in diary foods safety, microbiological analysis of dairy products, fermented milks and cheese, starters and probiotics, commercial practices and sources of information for regulation on microbial aspects of dairy foods.  2 lectures, 2 laboratories.
DSCI 540.prereqs: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology
DSCI 540.title: Graduate Dairy Microbiology

DSCI 541.description: Concepts and methodologies used in dairy industry and dairy food plants for assurance and control of the quality of finished product.  Basis for understanding physical, chemical and microbiological methods as they apply to quality evaluation of dairy foods.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
DSCI 541.prereqs: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology
DSCI 541.title: Quality Assurance, Quality Control and Food Safety

DSCI 560.description: Presentation and critical review of current research publications.  Methodological advances and applications in dairy food systems.  Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1-3 seminars.
DSCI 560.prereqs: Senior or graduate standing and approval of instructor
DSCI 560.title: Recent Developments in Dairy Science and Technology

DSCI 565.description: Plant site selection considerations, project management, plant design and layout, management of productivity maintenance, plant improvement project selection criteria, working with regulatory environment, community relations, and personal safety for overall industrial plant sustainability.  3 lectures, 1 activity.
DSCI 565.prereqs: DSCI 520; admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Science Technology
DSCI 565.title: Industrial Plant Considerations for Sustainable Operation

DSCI 570.description: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  1 to 4 seminars.
DSCI 570.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor
DSCI 570.title: Selected Topics in Dairy Science

DSCI 571.description: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1-4 laboratories.
DSCI 571.title: Selected Advanced Laboratory in Dairy Science

DSCI 581.description: Current findings and research problems in the field and their application to industry.  Group study of current problems of industry.  Current experimental and research findings as applied to production and marketing.  Repeatable for up to 3 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  1-3 seminars.  Credit/ no credit grading only.
DSCI 581.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor
DSCI 581.title: Graduate Seminar in Dairy Science

DSCI 582.description: Dairy plant operation, processing experience and production team dynamics.  Practical training and experience in dairy plant operations to allow efficient, safe and sanitary processing of dairy products manufacture in a team environment.  Total credit limited to 4 units.  2 laboratories.
DSCI 582.prereqs: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology
DSCI 582.title: Dairy Processing and Plant Management

DSCI 585.description: Advanced study, analysis and part-time work experience in the field; current innovations, practices, and problems in administration, supervision, and organization of business, industry, and government.  Must have demonstrated ability to do independent work and research in career field.  Total credit limited to 9 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.
DSCI 585.prereqs: Graduate standing and consent of instructor
DSCI 585.title: Cooperative Education Experience in Dairy Science

DSCI 599.description: Systematic research of a significant problem in Dairy Science.  Thesis will include problem identification, significance, methods, data analysis, and conclusion.  Students must enroll every quarter in which facilities are used or advisement is received.  Degree credit limited to 6 units.
DSCI 599.prereqs: Graduate standing and consent of instructor
DSCI 599.title: Thesis in Dairy Science

ECON 200.description: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.
ECON 200.prereqs: Sophomore standing and consent of department head
ECON 200.title: Special Problems for Undergraduates

ECON 201.description: Basic principles of microeconomics and macroeconomics. Emphasis on applications to current national and global economic issues. For majors requiring one quarter of economics. Not open to students having previous credit in ECON 222 or equivalent. 4 lectures. Crosslisted as ECON/HNRS 201. Fulfills GE D2.
ECON 201.title: Survey of Economics

ECON 221.description: Microeconomic principles. Marginal and equilibrium analysis of commodity and factor markets in determination of price and output. Normative issues of efficiency and equity. 4 lectures.
ECON 221.title: Microeconomics

ECON 222.description: Introduction to economic problems. Macroeconomic analysis and principles. Aggregate output, employment, prices, and economic policies for changing these variables. International trade and finance. Issues of economic growth and development. Comparative economic systems and economies in transition. 4 lectures. Fulfills GE D2.
ECON 222.title: Macroeconomics

ECON 270.description: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Schedule of Classes will list title selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.
ECON 270.prereqs: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor
ECON 270.title: Selected Topics

ECON 303.description: Economic analysis of the cause, extent and impact of poverty, discrimination and immigration and of the policies designed to address these socioeconomic issues.  Emphasis on the experience of African-Americans, Latinos, and women in the United States.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as ECON/HNRS 303.  Fulfills GE D5 except for Economics majors.  Fulfills USCP.
ECON 303.prereqs: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with a grade of C- or better; and ECON 201 or ECON 222
ECON 303.title: Economics of Poverty, Discrimination and Immigration

ECON 304.description: Analysis of economic systems as a set of mechanisms and institutions for decision making, and the implementation of decisions regarding income distribution, the levels of consumption and production, and the level of economic welfare.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE D5 except for Economics majors.
ECON 304.prereqs: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with a grade of C- or better; and ECON 201 or ECON 222
ECON 304.title: Comparative Economic Systems

ECON 311.description: Consumer behavior and the theory of demand; production, cost, supply functions; perfect competition; monopoly and oligopoly; labor markets.  4 lectures.
ECON 311.prereqs: ECON 201; or ECON 221 and ECON 222; and MATH 141 or MATH 221
ECON 311.title: Intermediate Microeconomics I

ECON 312.description: Game theory; risk, uncertainty and information; choice over time; asset markets; general equilibrium; welfare economics, externalities and public goods.  4 lectures.
ECON 312.title: Intermediate Microeconomics II

ECON 313.description: Analysis of national income, price level, employment, international trade and economic growth.  Development of the theory of national income determination.  Evaluation of roles of monetary and fiscal policy.  4 lectures.
ECON 313.title: Intermediate Macroeconomics

ECON 325.description: Analysis of the economy of less developed countries, and a survey of public policies designed to stimulate economic growth and reduce poverty.  Topics include financing development, technology, population problems, human capital, rural and urban development, trade policy and the economic relationships between developed and developing nations.  4 lectures.
ECON 325.prereqs: Completion of GE Area A with a grade of C- or better; completion of GE Area D3; and either ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 201
ECON 325.title: Economics of Development and Growth

ECON 330.description: Theory of comparative advantage, gains from trade, and recent developments in trade theory; examination of tariffs, quotas, exchange controls, other trade barriers and underlying policy issues; review of U.S.  commercial policy, GATT, the common market, regional and world economic organizations.  4 lectures.  Not open to students with credit in ECON 404 or equivalent.
ECON 330.prereqs: Either ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 201
ECON 330.title: International Trade Theory

ECON 337.description: Financial markets and institutions.  Structure of the banking industry and impacts of technological change in banking.  Structure and operations of the Federal Reserve.  Impacts of monetary policy on the economy.  4 lectures.
ECON 337.prereqs: Either ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 201
ECON 337.title: Money, Banking and Credit

ECON 339.description: Application of statistical methods useful in economics.  General linear regression model.  Specific issues and problems related to economic models:  multicollinearity, autocorrelation, heteroscedasticity, dummy variables, lagged variables, and simultaneous equation estimation.  Application and evaluation of selected examples of empirical economic research.  Microcomputer applications.  3 lectures, 1 activity.
ECON 339.prereqs: either ECON 221 and ECON 222; or ECON 201; MATH 141 or MATH 221, and STAT 252 or STAT 302
ECON 339.title: Econometrics

ECON 345.description: Economics of environmental resource management.  Conservation, sustainability, and dynamic efficiency in natural resources.  Effects of property rights and economic incentives on environmental and economic systems.  Design of local and global environmental policies to align market outcomes with social welfare goals.  4 lectures.  Not open to students with credit in ECON 431, ECON 432 or equivalent.
ECON 345.title: Environmental and Natural Resource Economics

ECON 395.description: Basic principles of algorithmic problem solving and computer programming for economics and business analytics applications.  Functions, iteration, recursion, and data structures.  Testing and debugging.  Design of algorithms and algorithmic complexity.  Stochastic programs.  Graph optimization.  Credit will only be granted in one of the following courses:  CSC 108, CSC 202, ECON 395.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.
ECON 395.title: Programming for Economics and Analytics

ECON 400.description: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units.
ECON 400.title: Special Problems

ECON 403.description: Application of basic tools of economics to American Industry.  Case studies of individual firms and industries.  Performance of various business structures, such as monopoly and oligopoly.  Effects of government regulation and antitrust policy.  4 lectures.
ECON 403.title: Industrial Organization

ECON 404.description: Theory of comparative advantage, neoclassical model of trade, offer curves and terms of trade, edgeworth boxes, valuation of factor inputs, effects of migration and mobility of funds, emerging growth and trade distortions, welfare effects of trade, and recent developments in trade theory.  4 lectures.
ECON 404.title: International Trade Theory

ECON 405.description: Nature of international payments, U.S.  balance of payments.  Theory and practice of foreign exchange rate determination under the gold standard, paper standard, and IMF system; international money and capital markets; problems of international liquidity and monetary stability.  4 lectures.
ECON 405.title: International Monetary Economics

ECON 406.description: Causes and measurement of business fluctuations.  Techniques of forecasting with microcomputer applications.  3 lectures, 1 activity.
ECON 406.title: Applied Forecasting

ECON 408.description: Applications of quantitative techniques to topics in microeconomic and macroeconomic theory.  Use of multivariate calculus and linear algebra in formulating static economic models.  Applications of statistical inference, estimation and forecasting in economic models.  4 lectures.
ECON 408.title: Mathematical Economics

ECON 409.description: Decision making in complex, realistic situations.  Simulation of random variables in Excel.  Risk aversion.  Subjective assessment of probabilities and correlations.  Decision trees.  Optimal bidding in auctions.  The winner's curse.  Moral hazard and risk sharing.  Repeated investment decisions under risk.  4 lectures.
ECON 409.title: Probability Models for Economic Decisions

ECON 410.description: Principles of rational decision making with respect to government revenues and spending.  Measurement of costs and benefits, and criterion selection.  Taxation, user fees, deficit financing, public goods, neighborhood effects and zoning.  Microcomputer applications.  4 lectures.
ECON 410.title: Public Finance and Cost-Benefit Analysis

ECON 413.description: Wage determination theory, basic economic factors that affect the labor movement, economic impact of union activities on employment, output, income, wages, prices, and national economic policy.  4 lectures.
ECON 413.title: Labor Economics

ECON 417.description: Analysis of ideas related to the development of economic theory in the Western civilization from the Greeks through the classical, neoclassical, and Keynesian to the current post-Keynesian concepts.  4 lectures.
ECON 417.title: Development of Economic Analysis

ECON 424.description: The role of money in our economy.  Focus on the links between monetary policy, interest rates, prices, housing markets, mortgage lending and overall economic activity.  Public policy issues relating to real estate markets.  4 lectures.
ECON 424.title: Monetary Economics

ECON 431.description: Economic dimensions of environmental abuse and protection.  Use of simple economic models in developing and evaluating environmental policies.  Overview of current environmental problems.  Issues related to the sustainability of economic growth at the national and international levels.  4 lectures.
ECON 431.title: Environmental Economics

ECON 432.description: Economic theory and public policies as applied to problems of natural resources and energy.  Dynamic resource and energy models developed with reference to public and private sector growth.  Application of the principles of capital theory emphasized.  Case studies.  Computer software applications in the study of natural resources and energy under uncertainty.  4 lectures.
ECON 432.title: Economics of Energy and Resources

ECON 434.description: Application of basic tools of economic analysis to problems of urban regions.  Causes and possible cures for inadequate growth rate, income levels, and the quality of life in urban regions.  4 lectures.
ECON 434.title: Urban Economics

ECON 435.description: Economic analysis of natural resource issues, policies and management with an emphasis on land and water use decisions in the western U.S.  Urban demand for water; water supply and economic growth; economic impacts of surface water law and institutions; economics of land management.  4 lectures.
ECON 435.title: Economics of Land and Water

ECON 440.description: Modern advanced econometric techniques with a special focus on those commonly used in academic and non-academic settings.  Discrete dependent variable models, instrumental variables, causal inference, nonlinear estimation, panel data, seemingly unrelated regression, distributed lag models, cointegration, and error correction models.  3 lectures, 1 activity.
ECON 440.title: Advanced Econometrics

ECON 460.description: Theory and practice of the development of economic analysis.  Steps in the formulation and execution of an economics research project.  4 lectures.
ECON 460.title: Research Methodology in Applied Economics

ECON 461.description: Selection and analysis of a problem under faculty supervision.  Problems typical of those which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Formal report is required.  Minimum 120 hours total time.
ECON 461.title: Senior Project I

ECON 462.description: Selection and analysis of a problem under faculty supervision.  Problems typical of those which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Formal report is required.  Minimum 120 hours total time.
ECON 462.title: Senior Project II

ECON 464.description: Analysis of selected economic topics and problems in directed individual or group-based projects, which require application of economic models, principles and theory to investigate important business, economic or social issues.  Formal report required.  4 seminars.
ECON 464.prereqs: Senior standing and two 400-level ECON courses other than ECON 460
ECON 464.title: Applied Senior Project

ECON 470.description: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.
ECON 470.title: Selected Advanced Topics

EDES 101.description: Familiarization with the professional fields of architecture, landscape architecture, structural engineering, construction, and city planning. Introduction to the college's programs as they relate to individual aptitudes. The design process. Visiting speakers. 2 lectures.
EDES 101.title: Introduction to Architecture and Environmental Design

EDES 123.description: Introduction to the individual's and societal relation with the designed and built environment, and its impact on natural resource consumption, identity, behavior, community, and human health, safety, and general well-being.  Study of the individual and role of design in community development and in making and preserving culture.  Diverse perspectives including designers, engineers, governing bodies, and individual users.  2 lectures, 2 discussions.  Fulfills GE D4.
EDES 123.title: Principles of Environmental Design

EDES 333.description: Skills and tools for employment acquisition or graduate school admissions.  Individual resume design and production.  Documentation of personal, professional and academic experience via written, oral and image based systems.  Employment interview dynamics.  Electronic and hardcopy portfolio production.  Internet marketing.  1 lecture, 3 activities.
EDES 333.prereqs: Third-year standing or permission of instructor
EDES 333.title: Professional Presentations

EDES 350.description: Interdisciplinary investigation of how human activities impact the Earth's environment on a global scale.  Examination of population, resource use, climate change, and biodiversity from scientific/technical and social/economic/ historical/political perspectives.  Use of remote sensing maps.  Sustainable solutions.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as AG/EDES/ENGR/GEOG/ISLA/SCM/UNIV 350.  Fulfills GE Area F.
EDES 350.prereqs: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with a grade of C- or better; and completion of GE Area B
EDES 350.title: The Global Environment

EDES 406.description: Collaboration of interdisciplinary faculty and guest speakers/panelists.  Introduction, illustration and analysis of concepts and principles for sustainability to be used in all aspects of environmental design.  Integration and application of knowledge of human and natural systems with environmental, social and economic concerns, from a global-to-local perspective.  4 lectures.
EDES 406.title: Sustainable Environments

EDES 408.description: A primarily project-based course, intended to aid students who wish to collaborate with the purpose of implementing sustainability principles by developing tools, process or designs, for community-based projects and proposals at various scales of planning, architecture and design of the human environment to address social, environmental and economic issues.  4 lectures.
EDES 408.title: Implementing Sustainable Principles

EDES 410.description: Advanced continuation of community-based projects defined and initiated in EDES 408.  Ongoing projects, individual and group, address variable scales of planning, architecture, and environmental design, with required completion at the end of the course.  2 seminars and supervised work.
EDES 410.title: Advanced Implementation of Sustainable Principles

EDUC 125.description: Issues associated with the successful transition from high school or community college to Cal Poly. Links fostered between student needs and campus resources. Coverage of academic policies and procedures, university study skills, goal setting, career planning, wellness and other topics relevant to student success. Not open to students with credit in UNIV 100. Credit/No Credit grading only. 1 lecture, 1 activity. Crosslisted as EDUC/UNIV 125.
EDUC 125.title: First Year Seminar

EDUC 207.description: Study of theories and research about the development and learning of children and young adolescents within diverse backgrounds, and application to teaching in public school settings.  Observations/interactions with children in school settings.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.  Crosslisted as CD/EDUC 207.
EDUC 207.prereqs: Sophomore standing; PSY 201 or PSY 202 or admission to the university with the intent to enter the MSTEP Program
EDUC 207.title: Children's Learning and Development in Educational Settings

EDUC 270.description: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Schedule of Classes will list title selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.
EDUC 270.prereqs: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor
EDUC 270.title: Selected Topics

EDUC 300.description: Historical, philosophical, and social foundations of public education in relation to school curriculum, instruction and dispositions of effective teachers.  Structured observation and participation in K-12 public schools with attention to instructional practices for diverse learners.  2 lectures, 1 activity.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.
EDUC 300.title: Historical, Philosophical, and Social Foundations of Public Education

EDUC 400.description: Individual investigation, research, studies or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 8 units, with a maximum of 4 units per quarter.
EDUC 400.prereqs: Junior standing and consent of instructor
EDUC 400.title: Special Problems for Undergraduates

EDUC 401.description: Discussion of contemporary educational issues, classroom practice, and professional dispositions; reflection on beginning fieldwork experiences in the classroom and their connection with educational theory and research.  Credit/ No Credit grading only.  3 seminars.
EDUC 401.prereqs: admission to the single subject credential program
EDUC 401.title: Field Experience Seminar

EDUC 405.description: Social, cultural, historical, political, economic, and educational factors and systems in Latin America and the United States that have contributed to and shaped Latino/a individual and group identity.  How factors affect individual acculturation in California and the United States and influence how Latino/as experience and participate with schooling in the United States.  3 seminars, 1 activity.
EDUC 405.prereqs: SPAN 202 with a grade of B or better, or appropriate score on placement exam, or consent of instructor
EDUC 405.title: Social, Historical and Cultural Influences on Latino/a Students in Education

EDUC 410.description: Inquiry into the social, historical, philosophical and psychological foundations of education with an emphasis on applying educational theory to practice.  Prepares Single Subject Credential Program students for classroom teaching.  4 lectures.
EDUC 410.prereqs: Admission to the Single Subject Credential Program
EDUC 410.title: Social, Historical and Ethical Perspectives on Teaching and Learning

EDUC 412.description: The role of culture, status, identity, and human development in public school experiences of diverse learners.  Organization and management of secondary school classrooms as related to adolescent development and issues of access to learning.  4 lectures.
EDUC 412.prereqs: Admission to the Single Subject Credential Program
EDUC 412.title: Access to Learning in a Pluralistic Society

EDUC 414.description: Principles, methods and practices of organizing curriculum, instruction, and assessment for secondary school subject areas, with an emphasis on backward design in curriculum development and assessment.  Site visits to local schools to allow analysis of planning, instruction, and assessment in secondary school classrooms.  4 lectures.
EDUC 414.prereqs: Admission to the Single Subject Credential Program
EDUC 414.title: Curriculum and Inquiry in Public Schools

EDUC 416.description: Theories and application of literacy learning, assessment and second language acquisition in content classrooms.  Observation of classrooms, tutoring English language learners, designing and teaching literacy lessons, planning and implementing assessments across content areas.  Recognition of the role of culture in language acquisition.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  3 lectures.
EDUC 416.prereqs: Admission to the Single Subject Credential Program
EDUC 416.title: Literacy, Language, and Culture in Content Area Classrooms

EDUC 417.description: Fieldwork in the secondary classroom related to literacy, language and culture for Agriculture Education candidates. Includes 1-3 hours of observation each week. Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance. Credit/No Credit grading. 1 activity.
EDUC 417.title: Literacy, Language, and Culture in the Content Area Classroom Fieldwork

EDUC 418.description: Differentiated instruction and further theoretical knowledge and skills needed for successful teaching of linguistically and culturally diverse learners, as well as students with special learning needs.  PACT assessments embedded in course prepare credential candidates for the teaching event.  3 lectures.
EDUC 418.prereqs: Admission to the Single Subject Credential Program
EDUC 418.title: Culturally Responsive Teaching in Diverse Classrooms

EDUC 419.description: Fieldwork in the secondary classroom related culturally responsive teaching in diverse classrooms for Agriculture Education candidates. Includes 1-3 hours of observation each week. Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance. Credit/No Credit grading. 1 activity.
EDUC 419.title: Culturally Responsive Fieldwork in Diverse Classrooms

EDUC 423.description: Patterns of classroom organization, application of reading programs, approaches, methods in English and Spanish, and supervised field experiences in elementary classrooms with bilingual students.  3 seminars, 1 activity.
EDUC 423.prereqs: Admission to the Spanish Authorization for Bilingual Educators (SABE) Program
EDUC 423.title: Bilingual Literacy

EDUC 427.description: Theories, methods, materials and assessment involved in the instruction of emergent bilingual students.  Bilingual, transitional, and English only programs compared across a historical framework.  Emphasis on an integrated language arts approach; theories of language acquisition.  3 seminars, 1 activity.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.
EDUC 427.title: Theories, Methods, and Assessment of First and Second Language Acquisition in Schools

EDUC 428.description: Introduction of foundational topics in literacy teaching and learning in K-8 schools with diverse populations.  Examination of concepts and theories underlying literacy learning and instruction, and relating research-based patterns of reading and writing development to features of the learner and learning environments.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.  3 seminars, 1 activity.
EDUC 428.title: Foundations of K-8 Literacy Teaching and Learning in Schools with Diverse Populations

EDUC 429.description: Integration of theory and practice for planning, instruction and assessment in a balanced, comprehensive, research-based K-8 literacy and language arts program to enable children of all abilities and background to read, write, speak, listen and think effectively.  4 seminars.
EDUC 429.prereqs: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation Program
EDUC 429.title: Learning to Teach K-8 Literacy in Schools with Diverse Populations

EDUC 431.description: Curriculum instruction and assessment concepts regarding teaching social studies to culturally diverse students in grades K-8, to promote civic competence and the development of elementary students' knowledge and reasoning in the social sciences.  4 seminars.
EDUC 431.prereqs: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation Program
EDUC 431.title: Learning to Teach K-8 Social Studies with Diverse Populations

EDUC 433.description: History, theories, and practices associated with contemporary bilingual education in California and the U.S.  Observation and limited teaching in bilingual classrooms.  Approximately one-half of the class taught in Spanish.  3 seminars, 1 activity.
EDUC 433.prereqs: Admission to the Spanish Authorization for Bilingual Educators (SABE) Program
EDUC 433.title: Foundations of Bilingual Education

EDUC 435.description: Curriculum, instruction, and assessment concepts regarding teaching mathematics for understanding to culturally diverse students in grades K-8, with emphasis on using manipulatives to promote elementary students' development of mathematical knowledge and reasoning.  4 seminars.
EDUC 435.prereqs: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation Program
EDUC 435.title: Learning to Teach K-8 Mathematics with Diverse Populations

EDUC 436.description: Curriculum, instruction, and assessment concepts regarding teaching science for understanding to culturally diverse students in grades K-8, with emphasis on teaching via inquiry to promote the development of scientific knowledge and reasoning.  3 seminars, 1 activity.
EDUC 436.prereqs: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation Program
EDUC 436.title: Learning to Teach K-8 Science with Diverse Populations

EDUC 438.description: Clinical experiences involving observation; limited lesson planning, instruction, assessment and reflection; growth as a professional educator and participation in school-related activities in K-8 public school classrooms.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.  Total credit limited to 4 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.
EDUC 438.prereqs: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation (MSTEP) Program
EDUC 438.title: Multiple Subject Clinical Practice I

EDUC 439.description: Discussion of contemporary educational issues and classroom practice; reflection on beginning clinical experiences in elementary education and their connection with educational theory and research.  Total credit limited to 4 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  2 seminars.
EDUC 439.prereqs: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation (MSTEP) Program
EDUC 439.title: Multiple Subject Clinical Practice Seminar I

EDUC 440.description: Characteristics, incidence, and etiology of individuals with exceptional needs.  Problems, assessment, and approaches toward accommodating students with exceptional needs in the regular classroom.  3 seminars, 1 activity.
EDUC 440.prereqs: EDUC 429, EDUC 431, EDUC 435, EDUC 436, EDUC 438 and EDUC 439
EDUC 440.title: Educating Individuals with Exceptional Needs

EDUC 442.description: Public school classroom experiences in general education and/or special education classrooms at the elementary level.  Teaching individuals and small groups.  Total credit limited to 4 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.
EDUC 442.prereqs: Acceptance into the Preliminary Special Education Credential Program or the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation (MSTEP) Program
